Award.AwardTitle: Community College Biology Education Research Meeting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas at Austin and De Anza Community College will be addressing the dearth of discipline-based education research, particularly Biology Education Research (BER), at the nation's community colleges. The project team will convene a meeting of national leaders in BER, community college biology teaching, action research, and community-based participatory research. The meeting will characterize the state of community college BER, including what issues or topics have been studied and where gaps exist. Further, it will generate a plan to identify constraints and affordances community college faculty encounter when conducting and publishing Biology Education (Bio-Ed) studies and a plan to identify support strategies that will enhance the number of faculty conducting and publishing community college Bio-Ed studies. Finally, the meeting will nucleate a network of individuals interested in conducting or participating in community college Bio-Ed studies.

Participants will represent diverse theoretical, practical, and institutional perspectives important to fostering BER in community colleges and will include journal editors, BER scholars, and community college faculty. The meeting will also include experts in the variety of research traditions that ensure active involvement of the community being studied and equitable consideration of community interests. The project will have three outcomes: 1) a meeting report that will be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal and a complementary set of editorials and letters to editors of other STEM- and Bio-Ed journals to draw attention to the report; 2) a set of plans for a collaborative research project to identify factors that enable or limit community college faculty in conducting and publishing BER; and 3) a network of individuals dedicated to fostering BER in community colleges and accomplishing emergent meeting goals. The meeting will also serve as a foundation for generating evidence-based strategies to address the dearth of BER at the community college level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Community colleges (CCs) have been broadly recognized as gateways to postsecondary education for low income and first-generation students. Almost half of all undergraduates are now attending CCs, which also enroll the majority of Latina/o, Native American, and Black undergraduates, and nearly half of all Asian and Pacific Islander undergraduates. Further, nearly half of students receiving STEM bachelor’s degrees complete some of their undergraduate coursework at CCs. For these reasons, CCs have been broadly recognized for their potential to influence early undergraduate learning and to broaden participation in STEM among traditionally underserved student groups.

Despite the key roles of CCs in the higher education landscape and their potential to support STEM interest and achievement, the existing biology educational research (BER) literature leaves CCs largely unexamined. The paucity of research on biology teaching and learning at CCs raises three concerns:

1)    We might be largely unaware of valuable teaching and learning strategies arising in CC biology contexts – particularly those related to advancing biology interest and learning among underserved student populations,

2)    We lack thorough understanding of the assets and needs of CC biology students, which represent nearly half of all STEM majors, and

3)    A lack of CC faculty involvement in BER could hinder national efforts to maximize the effectiveness of undergraduate biology teaching. When faculty systematically evaluate and reflect on their own teaching, they are more likely to teach more effectively. The relative lack of CC involvement in BER misses a significant opportunity to maximize learning of nearly half of all undergraduates. 

This project represented a first step in addressing the lack of BER performed at CCs and by CC faculty. We brought together a group of two- and four-year faculty, BER journal editors, and biology education researchers to discuss the current state of CC BER, identified challenges and benefits of engaging in CC BER, and prioritized strategies for supporting future CC BER. As a direct result of meeting activities, we have: 

-       Written and submitted a meeting report that has been accepted for publication in the open access biology education journal, CBE-Life Sciences Education. The report presents:

  • The current state of CC BER, including topics commonly addressed and areas open for research,
  • Descriptions of the challenges and benefits associated with conducting CC BER,
  • Suggestions of actions that diverse stakeholders can take to support CC BER, and
  • Descriptions of existing networks that currently support CC BER. 

-       Supported six CC faculty from the CC BER meeting to, along with the lead investigators, present and lead a discussion at the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER), which is the leading professional organization in BER. This quadrupled the representation of CC faculty at the conference, further disseminating outcomes of the CC BER meeting and raising awareness of issues related to CC BER.

-       Successfully advocated for reduced SABER conference registration costs for CC faculty so that more CC faculty will have the opportunity to attend this high profile event, learn more about BER, and share their research.

-       Embarked on the next phase of CC BER expansion, specifically pursuing funds to build a national CC BER network and to establish new initiatives that support CC faculty in conducting CC BER. 

In addition to these direct outcomes, this work has contributed to the success of meeting participants in conducting and publishing CC BER. Meeting participants have credited the CC BER meeting with providing the impetus to publish five different articles. Meeting participants also described the meeting itself as a networking and professional development opportunity.

All of these activities and products have nucleated a network of CC BER advocates and researchers. As this network expands, it will build capacity for more CC BER so that CC instructors may contribute to the knowledge of the broader BER community and all biology students may benefit from the new research this network produces.
